Definition:
• pestilence, epidemic, 
   • heaped up, as dead bodies.
the ghost or spirit of a living person seen by others, a sign of calamity. lit., many shadows.
quick, ready, as to do a kindly, deed, helpful.
fireworks (perhaps from Eng. scow [kao], as fireworks were first displayed from ships of explorers).
to pick up carefully, as food.
syllables repeated in chants, usually at ends of verses, similar to ēhē; also ahana and ahana kōkō lele, both meaningless.
better, well, well-being, fortunate, improved; to need (aho₃ + -na).
healthy, vigorous; strength and vigor, as of animal or plant; to grow rapidly, thrive.
a lover of wisdom, seeker after knowledge, philosopher, scientist, scholar; philosophy, science; scientific. lit., to desire wisdom.
modest, gentle, unassuming, unpretentious, unobtrusive, docile, decorous, meek, suave; meekness, modesty.
light of early dawn, sunset glow. lit., flaming road.
dark lines on stomach of a pregnant woman, converging near the navel. lit., burned path.

• a frequented and well-known path; to frequent such; 
   • to tread or trample, as on a taboo being broken. And.
railway, railroad track. lit., iron road.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the liver of Milu
two-sided, two-faced; facing one another, as cliffs on opposite sides of a valley.
name given to the kāmole plant used in hana aloha sorcery. lit., mutual love.
congregation, audience, assembly, gathering, crowd; to assemble.
a lowland perennial weed (Boerhaavia repens), with long, thin, prostrate branches, bearing small leaves and flowers. The swollen roots were used medicinally, acting as a diuretic. Anena on Niʻihau.
period of ten days; for ten days; to pass ten days.

• to follow, pursue, chase; 
   • to run, as for political office.
to raise or mount high, as waves; high, raised.
iron hoop or band, named for the king's guard under the monarchy.
ghost-ridden; haunted or unfriendly land. lit., ghost bile. cf. (Isa. 13.9) .

fathom: formerly the distance between tips of longest fingers of a man, measured with arms extended on each side; Catholic writers equated anana with one meter; to count by this measurement or by fathoms.
to turn off the course, wander, deviate.
to overturn, overthrow, upset; to till.
firmament, sky, blue vault of heaven.
a stench that draws flies; bad-smelling.
fishing with a pula stick or pūlale to drive fish into a net.
-na₁ form with hae₁,₂,₃; wildness; barking; tearing.
part of a fish's tail above and below the cleft.
to laugh merrily, giggle in glee; laughter.

• animation varying from fury and storm to power and majesty, animated, animation. 
   • violent; violence
   • anger, fury; furious
   • powerful
   • majesty.
an addition of water, as for mixing poi. Kauaʻi.
severe cramps, said to have often proved fatal.
day sacrifice; to sacrifice by daylight.

a small native fern (Schizaea robusta) found in high mountain wet areas believed to be the plant form of the sorcery goddess Pua; sometimes used as a psychological remedy to ward off the evil influence of Pua.  lit., Pua's memory. Hawaiʻi.
to perch high, as a bird.
consideration of grievances, disputes; councils for such consideration.
to straddle. fig., a tall thin person.
showy, pompous, vain, as of one's attire.
small land division, as cultivated for a chief.
to sew feathers to a band, as for a hat.

• broken piece, remnant, scrap, fragment; 
   • portion, 
   • balance, 
   • section, 
   • fraction, as in arithmetic.
to stand intently watching, as a thief [said to be the name of a legendary rat thief]; to stand precariously, as at the edge of a cliff.
a kind of lavender or purplish-red chrysanthemum. Probably lit., rose house, and named for someone called Rose, or whose house was called Hale Loke.

a romantic Oʻahu anti-hero who wooed, sometimes with success, the beautiful but fickle Puna princess, Kamalālāwalu. The account of the kilu (quoits) match contains some of the most beautiful of Hawaiian poetry. At the end of the tale the lovers apparently tire of one another. see ʻAikanaka₃.  lit., many houses.
portico; veranda with pillars; porch of pillars.

the two native species of Antidesma, medium-sized trees with hard wood, in the euphorbia family; leaves more or less ovate, fruits in grapelike clusters, purple, one-seeded. Formerly the wood was used for anvils for preparing olonā fiber, the fruit to color tapa red.
edge of a precipice or slope, brow of a hill.
name of a star associated with Hanakalauʻai, and Hakalauʻai; all were omens of pestilence or calamity.
smallpox (perhaps short for hana i ka pahu, build the coffin).
to be sturdy as steel. lit., iron steel (Eng.).
lashing, as of adze to handle; to lash. (hau₃ + -hana, nominalizer)
handful, scoopful; receptacle, as a dipper for kava.
one eighth; eighth part; a coin worth twelve and a half cents; a piece of silver money (Luka 15.8) .
calcareous earth resembling chalk or plaster.
to carry to and from, as gossip.
rain name associated with Poʻo-kū, Kauaʻi. lit., stepping upon pandanus flowers.
corpse, especially of one slain in battle; victim, human sacrifice; carcass (Mat. 24.28) , remains.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the drowned blow...
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the blow enters...
footrest; any place on which to step or tread; a stepping, treading.

• unpleasant odor, as of spoiling fish or meat, or volcanic sulphur; 
   • stench; tainted.
the planet Uranus, formerly called Hershel for its discoverer, Sir William Hershel, in 1781.
a rare native variety of dry-land taro, with dark purplish petioles and white corms; grown on Hawaiʻi.
quick step, quick time; to go fast.
want, need, necessity; lacking, destitute (Oihk. 22.23) , needy.
introduced, sweet-scented heliotrope (Heliotropium arborescens syn. H. corymbosum).
number, count, total sum, amount; grade or mark (evaluation).
thunder; to thunder. fig., passion, rage.

the swamp fern (Ceratopteris thalictroides), an edible, somewhat succulent fern, distributed through the tropics. It grows in mud or water, as around taro patches, in tufts about 30 cm high. The fronds are triangular and are finely divided into long, narrow parts. Young fronds are eaten with fresh-water shrimps.
same as the more common hiaʻā, indisposed to sleep, wakeful, sleepless...
redup. of hie, attractive, distinguished, dignified, noble, becoming...; superb.
to laugh at, ridicule, mock, tease, snicker, giggle; mockery, laughter.
kind of soft porous stone used to smooth and polish utensils; it is harder than the ʻana stone, which is used on wood.
depression or hole, as under water.
redup. and intensifier of hina, to fall.
same as the more common hiaʻā, indisposed to sleep, wakeful, sleepless...
redup. of hie, attractive, distinguished, dignified, noble, becoming...; superb.
kind of soft porous stone used to smooth and polish utensils; it is harder than the ʻana stone, which is used on wood.
depression or hole, as under water.

the swamp fern (Ceratopteris thalictroides), an edible, somewhat succulent fern, distributed through the tropics. It grows in mud or water, as around taro patches, in tufts about 30 cm high. The fronds are triangular and are finely divided into long, narrow parts. Young fronds are eaten with fresh-water shrimps.
redup. and intensifier of hina, to fall.
to laugh at, ridicule, mock, tease, snicker, giggle; mockery, laughter.
spittle passed from a dying master, according to the belief that his knowledge was thereby handed on.
to reel, lean or tilt sideways.
to force one's way, as through a crowd or undergrowth.
in devious ways; to ramble; be indirect.
mixed, snarled, entangled; to mix, snarl.
name of an unknown person, used something like so-and-so, usually followed by mā.
tattoo brand on the forehead of a kauā outcast, or on the forehead of the caught seducer of a high chief's wife. (see (Malo 70, figure 1))

intensification of hinu,  smooth and polished, lustrous, slick
   • bright, shining, lustrous, 
   • glossy, 
   • glittering, as of polished stones or shells; 
   • splendid; splendor.
young of ʻoʻopu, a fish, formerly caught in nets and greatly relished.  See saying, pā ʻili.

vague accounts (HM 214) mention this goddess as being born in the undersea land Kahikihonuakele (wet land Kahiki), and as floating on the sea and becoming a gourd bailer—Hinaikekā (Hina in the bailer) (KL. 235). In some stories she makes tapa in the moon (HM 220). She was also called Hinahanaakamalama (Hina foster-child of the moon), the name of Queen Emma's home in Nuʻu-anu Valley, Honolulu. lit., Hina in the moon. see ʻAikanaka₃; Hema.
Holy Roller [disparaging and offensive term for a member of a Pentacostal sect].
immature and inferior, as breadfruit falling prematurely.
to spread out, unfold, unfurl, as tapa, mats, clouds, wings; to extend, stretch, diffuse.
hone, whetstone, grindstone; to rub, grind.
bracelet of tusks of hog or dog.

• nape of the neck, shoulders (Puk. 12.34) ; 
   • main stem of a vine (Kep. 157).
a soft sweet sound, as of song; to sound softly, rustle, sough, as the wind
companion or contemporary of equal status.
to ice skate, ski. lit., ice run.
seaman, seafarer; to sail on the sea; sea voyage or cruise.
water ditch or course; to run in such courses; watery.
honeysuckle, a low, twining shrub (Lonicera japonica), from East Asia, with shortstemmed, oval leaves and fragrant tubular flowers that open white and turn yellow.
interrogation to incriminate, ensnare, or obtain information by roundabout methods, to question or quiz indirectly.
fruitful, productive, prolific; to bear many fruits; to lay many eggs.
result, conclusion, sequel, ending, destiny, fate, consequence, effect, last.
to kiss or smell repeatedly, sniff.
name of the capital city in the Hawaiian Islands lit., sheltered bay.

wild spiderflower (Gynandropsis gynandra), a cosmopolitan tropical hairy annual weed, native to Africa, in the caper family, 30 to 90 cm high, leaves five-parted; flowers spider-like, white with a purple tinge; fruit narrow, cylindrical capsule with many seeds.
a game in which player and opponent sat with legs crossed and tried to unseat each other; to play this game.

orange trumpet or sweetheart vine (Pyrostegia venusta syn. Bignonia venusta, B. ignea), an ornamental climber from Brazil, bearing early in the year many deep-orange flowers, hence chestnut-colored or light brown. lit. ripe fruit.
Hawaiian hula by many persons; to hula, of many.
a variety of banana. lit., many fruits.
tiny, yolkless egg. lit., wind egg.
redup. of hunehune and hune₁,₂; fine, dainty; stripped of all property.
a wheezing sound, as of asthmatic persons; a prolonged shrill cry.
bristling, tousled, as feathers, fur, body hair.
to seek, turn, of many and repeatedly.
a seine; to fish with the seine. lit., pull ropes (lau).
raft. lit., collection of floating boards.
Hudson, as the river or bay.
mixed, confused, haphazard, blurred; mix-up, confusion, jumble; to mix.
to pull or work together, cooperate.
kind of hard, black stone used for maika stones.
pool, meeting place of two or more streams.

• turning, turning place, 
   • overturning,
   • reversing, 
   • frontage.
ballrom dancing with partners, American dancing, ball; massed hula dancing; to dance.
ornamental comb decorated with feathers, with ornaments turned towards the back.

• a variety of large gourd or calabash, used as receptacle for tapa or garments, or for food offerings. 
   • fig., a woman, mother, wife.
light brown, bay, as a horse.
body hair, hair of eyelashes, fleece (Lunk. 6.37) , wool, fur; hairy.
intensifier of hulei; to toss and pitch, trot, swing.
second mate of a vessel. lit., binnacle turner.
a girding on of a loincloth; part of the loins covered by the malo.
to remove the bitterness, especially to pour off the bitter liquid and add fresh water to the preparation of arrowroot (pia).
tick used for mattresses and pillow covers, so called because they were stuffed with bird feathers.
name of a wind at Lahaina, Maui. lit., turn to the face of the cliff.
pattern in pāwehe plaiting, said to consist of a continuous row of red lozenges with their lateral angles touching.

a favorite and common native variety of banana, eaten raw or cooked. The fruit bunches are small, the skin thin, ripening yellow, the flesh salmonpink. (HP 115). This was one of the few bananas permitted women. Also hilahila. lit., yellow core.
to sew, of many or continuously.
white-flowered beach morning-glory (Ipomea stolonifera; synonym, I. acetosaefolia), distributed in tropical regions, with oblong to lyre-shaped leaves, and white flowers with yellow centers.
redup. and intensification of hune₂, very fine, delicate.
to sew to a backing, as feather leis.
grave, tomb, sepulcher, cemetery, mausoleum, plot in a cemetery.
a variety of taro used as offering to the gods; it may be qualified by the terms kea and ʻulaʻula.
a pestilence said to have come in the reign of Waia, believed the same as the ʻōkuʻu disease of 1804.
expert, wise person, wisdom. lit., closed nose, perhaps referring to deep diving and hence profound knowledge.
a kind of stone, as used for making maika stones.
name of a star. lit., in the mountain area occupied by gods or high chiefs.
rising upward, as the prow of a canoe. fig., scornful.
Let me see! Show it to me!
unexpected rain, as from a sunny sky; to rain thus.
stifling heat and humidity; acute discomfort, pain, grief, suffering; to be weary, stifling, sultry, stuffy.
visiting place in a grass house.
name of a sea breeze. lit., water drinking.
wood rollers laid under a canoe being hauled to prevent it from being scratched or damaged.
name of an odoriferous tree or shrub.
the sport of hurling lightweight hau wood spears; to hurl such spears. lit., hurl hau wood.
name of a star and of an ancient chief of Hawaiʻi.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the drowned blow.
to give generously or lavishly with the heart and not with expectation of return.
species of small colored shells, found particularly on Niʻihau; perhaps so called because the shells were used by chiefs.

a Mānoa beauty, the wife of Kauhi. In the legend gossips told Kauhi that she was unfaithful. He led her to a forest on Ka'ala mountain and slowly beat her to death and buried her under an ʻōhiʻa tree. Passers-by restored her to life. (HM 152-153). In the story as told by Westervelt (Old Honolulu, pp. 128-130), her cruel lover, a Waikiki chief, killed her three times; each time she was resuscitated by an owl god, Pueoaliʻi. lit., the pandanus of Puna.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the blow enters.
cutting, drawing of a line; turning point.
taboo on menstruating women, restricting them to the menstruating house. lit., place of dark night.
sanctified stone used by at priest in ʻanāʻanā sorcery.
a kind of ʻahi, a tuna. It is small, has a long pectoral fin, and reaches about 35 kilos in weight. lit., dark-striped.
tangent of a circle. lit., line that touches.
to walk with feet far apart, as an infant; to straddle, as on a horse.
thyme (Thymus vulgaris), from southern Europe, a small plant with small leaves, in the mint family, used to flavor food.
to offer food and prayers to a god or to the spirit of a deified person.
countryman; backwoodsman; sparsely inhabited place; countrified, rustic. lit., back person.
base of a quilt on which the pattern (lau) is appliquéd; this base is above the layer of cotton or wool. The pili is below it.
to walk with feet far apart, as an infant; to straddle, as on a horse.
base of a quilt on which the pattern (lau) is appliquéd; this base is above the layer of cotton or wool. The pili is below it.
countryman; backwoodsman; sparsely inhabited place; countrified, rustic. lit., back person.
to offer food and prayers to a god or to the spirit of a deified person.
thyme (Thymus vulgaris), from southern Europe, a small plant with small leaves, in the mint family, used to flavor food.
noisy; to make repeated noises, to talk incessantly; pealing, ringing, squeaking.
atonement, remission of sins; to pardon, absolve from sin, ransom. lit., forgive sin.

redup. of kala₁, to loosen, untie, free, release...; kala₄, rough, as sharkskin...
   • craggy, thorny, knotty. 
   • fig., rough in language, rude, harsh
to carve, cut, hew, hoe, etc., a little at a time; to whittle.
a kind of Zebrasoma, a fish.
a variety of taro; corm white, yielding gray poi; perhaps originated in Kalalau, Kauaʻi.
under control of a mysterious or supernatural power; magic.
a red- or yellow-flowered succulent (Kalanchoe blossfeldiana), a recent introduction.
crown, corona, diadem,  cf. also pua kalaunu.
to stretch, as the hide of an animal to be dried; taut.
division of land smaller than a moku or district; county.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., neat length.
star name, perhaps same as Unulau.
a land term of uncertain meaning and pronunciation commonly used in Kona, Hawaiʻi, in about 1848. Perhaps ulu is ʻulu, breadfruit.

a large tree (Calophyllum inophyllum), at home on shores of the Indian and western Pacific Oceans, with shiny, oblong leaves to 20 cm long, white flowers much like orange blossoms, and globose green fruits about 2.5 cm in diameter. The wood is hard and was formerly made into calabashes. Also kamanu, tamanu.
strength, energy, firmness of resolution, fixedness of purpose.
name of a star. lit., the light.
child of a chief; a petted child. fig., finicky, fussy.
selective, difficult to please. lit., person [who] chooses.
to impose a general taboo. lit., to tie the multitude.
yellow, yellow-hued; tapa dyed yellow with ʻōlena.

chameleon (RSV), mole (KJV).  (Oihk. 11.30)  Jackson's chameleon (Chamaeleo jacksoni) has been noted on Oʻahu since 1972, the green anole lizard (Anolis carolinensis porcatus) since, 1950; this is also commonly called chameleon. (McKeown 28–33).
combination of the juices of ʻōlena root and mānienie grass used medicinally.

small endemic trees (Broussaisia arguta), with large, oval, toothed leaves, in the saxifrage family; the small flowers and berries are arranged in wide, convex clusters. The flowers of one form have bluish-green petals; of another, red, another white, An old belief was that eating the fruit helped in fecundity; the increase of chiefs was compared to a fruiting kanawao. Varieties are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula.
priests of Kū serving in the luakini temple, said to be named for the first such priest.
half-step interval in music, a minor second.
to fluff out the feathers, as birds do in hot weather.
name of a mistlike rain famous at Hilo. lit., [rain that] lehua flowers drink. [An alternate interpretation is "rain that makes lehua flowers rustle."]
blanket, quilt, bedspread (general name); sleeping tapa.
to purse the lips, as in disapproval or disagreement.
large physically, both tall and stout; husky.
to go on hands and knees before high royalty; to act humbly.
to open, unfold, as a tapa; to expand, as a flower in bloom.
kind of malo dyed one color on one side, and another color on the other side (the wind often blows and exposes [kapeke] the color on the reverse side).
gathering of fish in schools near the surface of the sea.
house ridgepole, main ridge pole. see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 4
wind name. lit., the raging rain.
the many taboos inherited from chiefly ancestors or from the gods; person with many taboos.
probably same as Liolioiwawau, a star name.
star name, perhaps same as ʻAʻā, Sirius.

• double canoe, 
   • pair, span, yoke, 
   • two of a kind; 
   • to put together or pair, to yoke or harness together, 
   • to double in quantity; 
   • coupled. 
   • fig., two-natured.
ledge, step, jog, as on a cliff. [Elbert lists this form as varying with kaunu in his 1982 l-n doublets list (JPS Lexical Diffusion...) possibly the source of kaulu₇ ?]
to overlook faults of others. lit., to place shade.
resting place, place to put things, placement; restful, quiet (kau, to place + -lana, nominalizer).
name of a star that rises with Kawelolani in the month of ʻIkuā.
paper mulberry too old to be used for tapa.

• equality, equal, 
   • equation, 
   • equity, 
   • justice; just; dispense justice; 
   • impartial; treat fairly and impartially, 
   • mutual, parallel; 
   • to balance evenly, 
   • make alike, 
   • be in a similar situation, 
   • to arrive at the same time (For. 4:293); par.

• to observe closely, 
   • to direct attention to, 
   • aim at.
stick about 10 cm long with holes down its middle, used to hold gunwales in place while they are being sewed on with sennit.
name of a star appearing in the month of Hilina-mā. lit., the great forests of Life.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the liver of Milu.

• scales, 
   • weight; to weigh. 
   • fig., to consider, judge, estimate.
   lit., place pound (Eng.).

• to limit, restrict, moderate, limitation, ration.
   • mark a border or boundary, 
   • set a deadline; deadline.
pole set up as indicative of taboo.
beloved wife or friend, beloved friendship united in such close relationship. lit., place clinging.
telegraph; to send a telegram or cable. See song, (EM 61).
coarse tapa, as made from māmaki bark or from the waste of better grade tapa.
consecrated oil and balm, as used in confirmation services; chrisom.
telegram; to send a telegram or cable.
carob tree (Ceratonia siliqua), somewhat like the algaroba; in (Luka 15.16)  Hawaiian hua keratio corresponds to English pods (RSV) or husks (KJV).

• interruption; to interrupt; 
   • choppy, as the sea.
same as liʻawahine, blossoms of kukui.
a fresh-water fish similar to nāwao.
term used in 1848 land claims, perhaps a steep hill.
name of one of the places, as under a tapa, where the noʻa stone was hidden in the game of pūhenehene.

• majestic, imposing; 
   • tall, 
   • strong, 
   • having poise that commands admiration.
rain associated with Panaʻewa, Hawaiʻi. lit., quenching lehua flowers.

• fine, light rain, 
   • wind-blown spray, 
   • drizzle; to shower lightly.

up-and-down motion, as of a trip hammer.
   redup. of kimo₁, (play) a game similar to jacks...
   redup. of kimo₂, to bob, as the head; to bend or fall forward...
extinguishing, putting out, snuffing out of life.

name of the outside, decorated sheet of tapa in the kuʻinakapa, bed coverings; the four inner layers were white, contrasting with the decorated kilohana. Hence extended meanings: best, superior, excellent.

• to throw, toss; 
   • to deposit, as, bones of the dead.
name of a mountain rain. lit., countless lehua blossoms.
probably Natica gualteriania. lit., sand-dwelling kio (mollusk).
young, immature, as flora or fauna.

lance for boils, sores, as of fishbone or a sharp stick; abortion stick; this term, like that referring to other sharp things (shark, sea urchin, eel) is applied to chiefs as indicative of the sharp defense of the chief against contact with his taboo person, or infringement of his taboos.
a large remainder, a balance, remnant; to be many remaining.
to edge away, back away, creep, move cautiously and carefully, as a frightened or feeble person.

• nude, naked; bare, 
   • alone, by itself.
spacing, space, as between rows of stitching in a quilt; width of pandanus strips used in plaiting, weft.
name of a wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
to stretch out; stretched out, long and thin.
pheasant (Phasianus colchicus torquatus), the showy ring-necked pheasant. lit., creep go on.
fragrant, as air laden with the perfume of flowers, sometimes said of the breath. lit., creeping flowers.
name of a law in the time of Kū-aliʻi safeguarding the rights of commoners.
humble, modest, thoughtful, kind. cf. kolokolo, creeping, as in respect to a chief, and akahai, modest.
a native shrub (Cassia gaudichaudii) with greenish-yellow flowers and thin flat pods.
stone, as used with octopus lures.
evil possession resulting from sorcery. cf. noho.
same as konoʻele (darkness, as of a forest; said also of the inside of thighs thought to be darkened by the chafing of the malo; somewhat darker than konouli...), but perhaps less dark.
(more commonly Tuahine). Name of a misty rain famous in Mānoa, Oʻahu, named for Kuahine, who turned to rain after the murder of her daughter, Ka-hala-o-Puna; the rain is also in other localities.
coping on the top of a building.
hornet, wasp, scorpion (kopiana is the usual name for scorpion).

• to scribble.
   • redup. of kope₁ to rake, scratch...
name of a quilting design. lit., turtle back.
medicine made of pua kala plant and taken as treatment for pyorrhea, neuralgia, stomach ulcers.
four generations removed, of a great-great-grandparent or great-great-grandchild, as kupuna kualua, moʻopuna kualua; for some speakers, three generations removed.
five generations removed, of a great-great-great-grandparent or great-great-great-grandchild, as kupuna kuakolu, moʻopuna kuakolu, for some speakers, four generations removed.
distant legendary place, as the brink of the nether world into which spirits leaped. Also Leinaakeakua.
pugilist in the high chief's court, a muscular young man who might also be asked to massage a chiefess or have relations with her.
a sea creature, perhaps Aplysia dactylomela or A. juliana.
a taboo chief who had the right to carry a pala fern in ceremonies.
taboo night proclaimed in month of ʻIkuwā during the makahiki festivals.
verdant mountain, where all thrives and grows.
to thicken, as scrambled eggs; to become pasty; to gel.
children of a high chief by a secondary wife or of second degree collaterality.

• heap, pile; to heap or pile up; heaped up; 
   • numerous.

• long repetitious prayer said at luakini dedication ceremonies, 
   • hence repetitiousness in general; 
   • to repeat, 
   • to wander, digress, perhaps senselessly.
sycamine, a tree mentioned by Jesus; according to (Harper), a mulberry, probably the black variety.
name of a breeze blowing from the northwest of Niʻihau. lit., strike Lehua (Island).
method of making a hat lei by sewing leaves and flowers to a pandanus strip; to make such a lei. lit., string on a base.
a rough lemon (Citrus limonia), liked for the fragrance of the skin, but too sour to eat. lit., having the nature of the kane skin fungus.
a crab, often qualified by the terms kea, white, and ʻōhuluhulu, hairy.
a stringing together, as of leis.
a stringing together, as of leis.
name of a breeze blowing from the northwest of Niʻihau. lit., strike Lehua (Island).
a crab, often qualified by the terms kea, white, and ʻōhuluhulu, hairy.
a rough lemon (Citrus limonia), liked for the fragrance of the skin, but too sour to eat. lit., having the nature of the kane skin fungus.
sycamine, a tree mentioned by Jesus; according to (Harper), a mulberry, probably the black variety.
method of making a hat lei by sewing leaves and flowers to a pandanus strip; to make such a lei. lit., string on a base.

having no wife, children, or relatives (name derived from a lone mulberry tree growing in a cave at Kūloli, Kona, Hawaiʻi, which was known as ka wauke kū kahi a Kūloli, the lone mulberry tree of Kūloli); also said of any very young wauke plant.
to tilt, rock, reel, sway, toss and pitch; wobbly, shaky, unsteady. fig., insecure, hesitant.
accustomed to, acquainted with, intimate with; customary, usual, chronic.

right, privilege, concern, responsibility, title, business, property, estate, portion, jurisdiction, authority, liability, interest, claim, ownership, tenure, affair, province; reason, cause, function, justification; small piece of property, as within an ahupuaʻa; blood relative through whom a relationship to less close relatives is traced, as to in-laws.
concoction made of gourd vine and kukui nuts.
name of a disease, perhaps jaundice.
female who has produced young, as of horse, cow, pig, chicken; to have produced young, female; root with many sprouts, propagating plant (rare); major source.
itch, scabies; scabby skin condition; to itch.
topic, subject (as topic of discourse or grammatical subject); matter. (kumu₁ + -hana, nominalizer.)
a mat motif with a continuous row of red lozenges with their lateral angles touching.
an edible bivalve found at Pearl Harbor, possibly Chama species.
unicorn, rhinoceros. lit., brow with protruding horn.
a variety of sugar cane, usually free tasseling, heavy stooling, and with rather semierect to recumbent growth; large, long heavy tops.
rubber; automobile tire; elastic, rubbery. lit., horse scrotum.
an endemic genus of small trees (Broussaisia), with a few forms, in the saxifrage family. lit., mountain sprout.
to walk gently, slowly, softly; to lag behind.
same as noio, a tern. lit., white brow.
name of a star. lit., demigod beneath the heavens.
to talk incongruously, mixing proper and improper talk.
crook, protuberance, hump; bent out, convex.
torch fishing; torch; to go torch fishing.
both flowering and aromatic-leaved pelargoniums also called rose geraniums.
deep booming sound, as of distant surf.
name of a star. lit., the light floats.
uninterested in religion, indifferent to religion.
vagabond, drifter, one as useless as pandanus leaves adrift in the sea. lit., floating pandanus leaf.
legendary name for broad leaves of the first taro, said to have been born of a woman.
a kind of ʻoʻopu, a fish.
brightly colored butterfly fish (Chaetodon quadrimaculatus and C. umimaculatus). This name may be qualified by the terms kapuhili, kīkākapu, maha uli, nuku ʻiʻiwi or nuku ʻiwi, and wiliwili.
confused, repetitious, mixed, incoherent, as speech; miscellaneous; irregular-shaped, as some leaves.
wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.  lit., kamani leaf.
cooperation, joint action; group of people working together; community food patch; to work together, cooperate. lit., many hands.
design on a Niʻihau mat. lit., many torches or lama tree leaves.

a variety of sugar cane with green and yellow striped canes and leaves; used in sorcery, because of the meaning of laukōnā, to break the influence of the hana aloha love magic and change love into hatred.
to cooperate, work together, as of experts; to concentrate on the same task; to pool talents.

• sin, sinner, sinful; to sin, transgress.
   • delinquency, delinquent, 
   • offense; 
   • evil.
workman, laborer; industrious; to do labor, work.
star in the Milky Way, perhaps Antares. lit., south lehua flower.
earth-clinging rainbow. lit., wet cowry shell.
strong-backed, muscular, of strong physique, bulging with muscles.
getting, acquiring, taking, carrying, acquisition; movement, as of dancing hands.
to drift apart; to depart, as in death.
to study both sides of a question; to act impartially. lit., take two.
lit., fruit lei, so called because the flowers are round like a fruit.
a broad flat, as of coral, lava, reef.

the flower of the ʻōhiʻa tree (Metrosideros macropus, M. collina subsp. polymorpha); also the tree itself. The lehua is the flower of the island of Hawaiʻi, as designated in 1923 by the Territorial legislature; it is famous in song and tale. see nāpolupolu, pōkiʻi₁, ʻūpolu. fig., a warrior, beloved friend or relative, sweetheart, expert (see lehua₉). The plant has many forms, from tall trees to low shrubs, leaves round to narrow and blunt or pointed and smooth or woolly. The flowers are red, rarely salmon, pink, yellow, or white. The wood is hard, good for flooring and furniture, formerly used for images, spears, mallets. (Neal 637–8). It grows abundantly in wet areas (see ex., ʻūpolu). It was believed that picking lehua blossoms would cause rain. For rain and wind names associated with lehua see Kanilehua, Kinailehua. Kinimakalehua, Kiu Wai Lehua, Līlīlehua, Moanianilehua, Moelehua. see also lū lehua, Moaʻe Lehua, ʻōiwi₂ (chant). cf. Marquesan heʻua

• circuitous, roundabout, indirect, 
   • turning, twisting, 
   • unstable, fickle, changeable, inconstant, 
   • double-tongued, 
   • variable.
to shine, glitter, sparkle, as dew in the sun.
legion; a large number (Mar. 5.9, 15) ; used figuratively of one possessed by the devil or intoxicated.
to swing on a koali vine. lit., dragonfly leap.
fine windblown rain spray, dust, mist; to fall as fine rain.
a weapon, a large shark tooth set in a piece of wood about 6.4 cm long, with a string loop for attaching to the finger (probably from lei o manō, a shark's lei).
spring, leap, bound; place to leap from.
shark-sucker, remora (Echeneidae spp.); it clings to large fish, such as swordfish, marlin, bonito, shark.
a musical interval of an octave.
toothed, sharp-pointed design, as in tapa.
to die suddenly, as by stroke or accident.
a slowpoke; slow, sluggish, disinclined to get up.

a red seaweed (Halymenia formosa) with flat blades bearing fringed and irregular margins, with a variety of colors ranging from red to yellow; common allusion to swirling in water resembling movement of pāʻū in dancing. Also called leheleheʻīlio, lepelepeohina, limupepeohina, pāʻūohiʻiaka.
split or crack in wood, running with the grain.
part of a heiau temple where human sacrifices were offered.
to hang in fringes or tatters.
name of a gusty, wintry wind.
(but some persons limit limalau cooperation to canoe and house building).
labor, laborer, worker, employee; industrious, busy. staff (HE). cf. hana lima under lima₁.
a small native herb (Acaena exigua), growing in bogs, only on top of West Maui and Kauaʻi, the narrow, fernlike leaves forming a rosette.
wind associated with Haʻena, Kauaʻi.  lit., turning hand.
dressed to perfection, beautifully decorated, ornamented.
name of a star, and name for the southern sky. (Wawaʻu is a widely distributed Polynesian place name) see (PN 229).
overgrown or covered with moss, seaweed, or any limu.

• to handle, use the hands; 
   • to pilfer, filch.
wall and gable plates in house.  see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 3

• rule, 
   • custom, 
   • manners, 
   • code, precept, law; 
   • principle, as of a political party.
thatching and trimming, of a house. lit., handle leaves.
changeable, fickle, unstable, inconstant, inconsistent, variable; turncoat.
wall and gable plates in house.  see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 3
thatching and trimming, of a house. lit., handle leaves.
changeable, fickle, unstable, inconstant, inconsistent, variable; turncoat.
a legendary fire guardian and the name of the makahiki image.
uneven, full of holes, rough, bumpy, as a road.
betrothal gift, as sent from one family to another.
news spread far and wide; news so well bruited that everyone has heard repeatedly; spread far, of news.
halo or rainbow around sun or moon. lit., polished pit.
name of a design used on Niʻihau mats.
the god of the annual fall harvest makahiki circuit of the islands when taxes were collected. He was symbolized by a tapa banner suspended on a mast with a tiny carving of a human head at the top.
a banner held up by two staffs.
easily scattered, dispersed, blown away; scaly, as skin. lit., scattered fine.
to be at leisure, enjoy pleasant sorroundings and associates, live in comfort and ease, enjoy oneself, relax, be content. (see lua-, -na.)
a laboring, wearying, caring for, etc.
upper part of a pillar, chapiter.
a small creeping native fern (Grammitis tenella), with simple narrow fronds 5 cm long or longer, each bearing none to many round spots of spores.
rude, disrespectful, saucy, overbearing; encroaching on the property or rights of others. lit., double temple.
flourishing, of luxuriant growth, lush, thriving.
disbelieving, cynical, skeptical, as of religion; irreligious, atheistic.
the directional mai plus lā, there, then.
to spread out; to smooth out, as a cloth to dry; to extend, expand. see hola₁ and ex. heʻe₁.
name of a star used in navigation.
hasty; active, as a child into everything.
mockery, derision, spying (rarely used without hoʻo-).
to extol, praise, treat as a chief or great favorite, indulge, spoil, favor.
fine mesh or weft, as of net or mat.
to step lightly, touch lightly, to skim lightly.
ancient festival beginning about the middle of October and lasting about four months, with sports and religious festivities and taboo on war; this is now replaced by Aloha Week.
a limpet, Celluna exarata; flesh within ʻopihi shells.
rocky patches where sweet potatoes or taro were cultivated (For. 6:165); soil consisting of coarse sand, cinders, or gravel.
presents made at the birth of a child.
hardhearted, unfriendly; troubled, vexed. lit., tough face.
lead horses or oxen in a team.
numerous, many, much, in great quantities (sometimes used with implication of chiefly mana). lit., eight eyes.
taut, as a rope. lit., tight mesh.
beach, shore, coast near a point (lae).
small outlets for water through banks of taro patches; small waterways; water sources.
uniform, as in color, style, clothes. lit., similar face.
fine-meshed, as a mat of medium weft, as 1.5 cm.
bargain; profitable, reasonable in price or in conduct.
name of a strong, blustering wind at Nuʻu-anu; to blow, of this wind.
a seaweed. lit., parent of the limu kohu.
mourning, wailing, lamentation; to wail, lament, weep for joy.
place where a stream disappears in the ground.
common pronunciation of malaila, but not so written.
shelter or protection of any kind, often humble; shady.
canoe bait carrier, some two or three fathoms long, with holes pierced in the sides and bottom to admit water, as used for bonito fishing.
to die, of several; to wilt, wither, of plants.
name of a gentle breeze associated with Kōloa, Kauaʻi, Hāna, Maui (For. 5:97), and Kailua, Oʻahu.
not well acquainted, somewhat unaccustomed to or unfamiliar with.
a small native tree (several varieties of Pelea hawaiensis), with oblong leaves and four-parted fruit capsules; related to the mokihana.

discomfort of the stomach, or indigestion, with gas and often diarrhea, thought to be caused by wrong diet or by excessive handling of animals, such as kittens or puppies, which might also become sick; to suffer thus; great grief, as over the loss of a loved one; to grieve. lit., swollen stomach.
third or highest platform of the lana-nuʻu mamao (oracle tower), where the high priest conducted services.
name of a star, said to appear in the first night of the month Nana and to vanish after the night of Muku. lit., female power.
young of the kawakawa, a fish.
type of fish (KL. line 158), perhaps same as mamo, mamamo, mao.
stage of manini, a fish, said to be larger than ʻōhua and smaller than manini.
place name at Kīlauea Volcano, Hawaiʻi.
grudge, resentment, spite; unforgiving, to nurse revenge.
descendant of old chiefs of a land; established, ancient, as a family.
to do it continuously, repeat; repetitious; repeating.
hot, heat, but less hot than ʻenaʻena; unapproachable, as of a high taboo chief.
to ration food or water, as in time of drought.

legendary race of small people who worked at night, building fish ponds, roads, temples; if the work was not finished in one night, it remained unfinished; also Melehune. see ʻeʻepa. (Luomala-1951) convincingly refutes the theory that Hawaiʻi was settled by Menehune before the arrival of the first Hawaiians.
redup. of miki₁, quick, active, nimble, prompt, alert...; energetic.

the Chinese rice flower (Aglaia odorata), a shrub or small tree in the mahogany family, from south China and Indo-China, grown ornamentally for the handsome leaves and fragrant flowers, which are tiny, round, and yellow; clusters of them are used for leis.
most beautiful, of dress, finery, ornaments.
to praise, exalt; to give thanks; to treat as a favorite.
most beautiful, of dress, finery, ornaments.
to praise, exalt; to give thanks; to treat as a favorite.

the Chinese rice flower (Aglaia odorata), a shrub or small tree in the mahogany family, from south China and Indo-China, grown ornamentally for the handsome leaves and fragrant flowers, which are tiny, round, and yellow; clusters of them are used for leis.

orange and white champak (Michelia champaca and M. longifolia), tall trees with smooth gray trunks, from the Himalayas, related to the magnolia, bearing many-parted, orange or yellow flowers (M. champaca) or white flowers (M. longifolia), which are especially fragrant at night. (Neal 357) The orange and white species may be distinguished by qualifying miulana with the colors melemele and keʻokeʻo. The Chinese name for the white species is pak-lan, but cf. pakalana .
to prize greatly, value greatly, especially of something in danger of being lost; to value, place great value on; value, worth.

striped tapa; an outer sheet (kilohana) for bed covers, as made by laying a red cloth or tapa over a white tapa in long panels with intervening white spaces, and then beating it into the tapa; striped.

a goddess who came with Pele from Kahiki and lived in Kaʻieʻie Channel between Kauaʻi and Oahu. She had two forms: one of a woman as beautiful as, a lehua tree laden with blossoms, the other of a red moano fish. When Māui tried to draw the islands together, Moano and others snagged his hook into a rock (Pōhakuokauaʻi) which was then pulled to Kaʻena Point. Māui caught Moano's fish body and laid it on a shrine. Her spirit returned to Kahiki, but it returned later to Kauaʻi, Oahu, and finally to ʻŌlaʻa, Hawaii. lit., great goatfish, the lehua blossom.
striped, of three colors of about the same width and lying parallel.
striped, of two colors of about same width and lying parallel, as of tapa.
to sleep in a similar way; parallel.
a plant resembling kiliʻoʻopu, a sedge.

a native tree (Pelea anisata), found only on Kauaʻi, belonging to the citrus family. The small, leathery, cube-shaped, anise-scented fruits, which change from green to brown, are strung in leis; they represent Kauaʻi in the leis of the islands, as designated in 1923 by the Territorial legislature. The large leaves are also fragrant.
short for moana uli, dark blue sea.
geometry. lit., base for measuring land.
thief, robber; to rob, plunder, take by force.
an annelid worm, resembling a centipede.
to swarm, as flies, bees, mosquitoes.
river, river mouth; pool near mouth of a stream, as behind a sand bar, enlarged by ocean water left there by high tide; estuary.

• rattling, as of a window; 
   • rustling, as of paper.
stacte [sweet spice used in ancient Hebrew incense].
a variety of white sweet potato.
family discord, quarrel. lit., nose biting.
to glimmer through, as light through a small opening; to begin to open, as eyes of a young animal; to twinkle.
rough, of a sea with high waves; to form high waves.
spider (Araneida); today this is the house spider, formerly the outdoors spider.
to pull away from; contrary, disdainful (perhaps from nanā, surly, and huki, pull).
weatherworn, as old canoes or persons who have weathered the storms of life. lit., ocean wave.
fish-basket trap made of ʻinalua vines, used for small fish. lit., double-meshed groove.
to writhe and twist, as an eel.
shuffling, scratching, thumping sound; to sound thus
the native Hawaiian sumach (Rhus sandwincensis, synonyms R. semilata var. sandwicensis and R. chinesis var. sandwicensis) a shrub or small tree, with light, soft, tough wood.
fluttering the wings; contracting the muscles, flexing the muscles, as preparing for exercise.
sheer and smooth, as a cliff.
design on Niʻihau mats consisting of a series of pointed notches, called kulipuʻu elsewhere. lit., twisting loose tooth.

native geraniums (Geranium spp.), shrubs and small trees found only at high altitudes in Hawaiʻi. They have small, ovate, green or silvery leaves, edged or tipped with teeth, and reddish or white flowers. lit., cold dwelling.
blossoms of the olopua, a tree.
diarrhea; to have symptoms of diarrhea; disgust; to be vile.
name given to a kind of sled obtained from Captain Cook; it is said to have had supernatural qualities.
to move quickly, as a gust of wind.
to move quickly, as a gust of wind.
to rise and fall, as the sea.
name given to a kind of sled obtained from Captain Cook; it is said to have had supernatural qualities.
dumping ground, refuse or rubbish dump.
name reported for a minor illness (no data).
wind off Waiʻanae, Oʻahu (PH 161), and associated with Naue, Kauaʻi (For. 5:97). lit., pandanus ensnarement.
name of a star or for the Milky Way. lit., eastern long row.
landing place, as of canoes (paena waʻa) or of waves (paena nalu); landing.

a large native tree (Osmanthus sandwicensis), to 19 m high, in the olive family. It bears narrow or oblong leaves, yellowish flowers, and blue 1.3 cm- long fruits. The hard wood, dark-brown with black streaks, was used for spears, adze handles, and digging sticks. cf. nonohina.
name of a death-bringing prayer or for a heiau dedication.
name of a Kauaʻi wind. lit., sand carrying.
taboo enclosure about a chief's house or about a heiau.
to have connections with important or influential persons.
those in charge of a chief's property.
same as kala liʻiliʻi, a fish (see kala₃).
untrue, false; untruth (contraction of pāhili, variable, and lau, much).

• to march, 
   • drill, 
   • parade, 
   • pass to and fro; 
   • to practice firearms.

• similar to mailani, to extol, praise, treat as a chief or great favorite, indulge, spoil, favor... but often pejorative; 
   • to spoil.
to make a great pet of; to treat with great favor.
a pushing, thrust, hurling, piercing, etc., as of an ihe spear.
loosened, slipping off; to loosen, get loose; weakening, as a voice.
demented, to behave as if crazy.

a variety of sugar cane, with different names on different islands. A deep purple-red and green striped cane resembling ʻakilolo but the leaves somewhat variegated; also producing mutants of solid yellow and red, like nānahu, pilimai.
old name of an illness (no data).

the Chinese violet (Telosma cordata), which has yellowish-green flowers. [(Neal 700-701): A vine with slender, cylindrical, downy branches, native to India and China, grown for the delightfully fragrant flowers, which in Hawaii are popular for leis. ... The narrow, cylindrical, podlike fruits sometimes develop in Hawaii. A Hawaiian name, pakalana, is sometimes applied to this vine, a name rightfully belonging to Michelia alba (cf miulana)]
rotten, as a banana stump; overripe, as banana fruit with juice dripping and black skin, as used in medicine.
wrinkled, coarse, as skin or bark; encrusted, as with grime or rust.
na form of pai₂; to lift; lifting, swelling or breaking, as waves.
to dress in tight-fitting garments; buttoned up tightly.
sound of a stone falling into water; to fall with a sound; plump.
overcooked to the point of falling apart, as meat (less common than moʻa palahē).
turning away in embarrassment, confusion, or humility, concealment of true feelings.
map (less used than palapalaʻāina). lit., land document.
a surgeonfish (Acanthurus dussumieri), famous for a strong odor.
young of the lai, a fish.
sickly, withered, stunted, puny, as unhealthy plants or people.

an endangered gray, yellow, and white Hawaiian honey creeper (Psittirostra bailleui, P. kona); endemic to the island of Hawaiʻi. Its bill is especially suited for opening māmane tree pods. Its only home is on Mauna Kea, Hawaiʻi.

• boundary, border, 
   • limit, 
   • margin, 
   • juncture, 
   • separation, 
   • partitioning; 
   • terms of a fraction.
safe, saved, rescued; convalescent; to ward off, brush aside, rescue, protect; to recover from illness; defense, savior, safety, security. (pale₁ + -kana, nominalizer).
a legendary land of plenty and joy, said to be on Hawaiʻi, where chiefs' children were raised; now a place name on several islands. lit., green cliff. see chant, pulelo and saying, glory.
small weak taro shoot (preceded by ke).

• end, closing, closure, very last, conclusion, finish, cessation, 
   • breaking off or cutting short; 
   • definitive, 
   • classic.
to move in, of the tide.
to strike gently, as the butt of a coconut midrib used as a pole for catching crab.
fending off, warding off, pushing aside.
redup. of papau, deeply engaged... finished... united...;  everyone.
face of a clock or watch.
rain name associated with Olowalu, West Maui.
to contend with, make war on,
to betray one's relatives or those close (koke) to one.
interception, shutting off, as from view; to block.
of the same species, class, rank.
a star that appears in the night of Muku in the month of Māhoe Mua, and remains visible through the month of Māhoe Hope; it follows the star Ululoa, and was considered the latter's "servant."
to gird the waist tightly, to stretch, make taut.
a star observed by priests, in the month of Kaulua and visible through the month of Ikiiki.
a small bright star that appears on the night of Hilo in the month of Welo and stays all the month.
to baptize, baptismal; baptism. also papakema.
name of a star, said to appear early on the night of Muku.
filthy, dirty, nasty, indecent, unclean, vulgar, lewd, obscene.
picul, as used for the sale of sandalwood.
to present, as arms (petikini i nā pū).
to turn about; to turn and go back.
propeller, as of an airplane. Niʻihau.
horn of an animal; trumpet or horn made of an animal's horn. (Hal. 118.27)  lit., iron ear.
wind associated with Kaʻawaloa, Hawaiʻi. lit., near pandanus.
temporary bed made of dry ʻilima branches, dried banana leaves and grasses, over which a mat or two were spread.
to pick up, as a rooster picks up food.

a rattlebox (Crotalaria pallida, formerly known as C. mucronata), known in many tropical countries, a small, weedy, shrubby legume with three-parted leaves, yellow flowers striped with red, and many-seeded pods to 5 cm long.
to pinch or squeeze, as in milking.
account, reckoning, as of an estate; invoice.
account, reckoning, as of an estate; invoice.
to pick up, as a rooster picks up food.
wind associated with Kaʻawaloa, Hawaiʻi. lit., near pandanus.
temporary bed made of dry ʻilima branches, dried banana leaves and grasses, over which a mat or two were spread.

• sad, sorrowful, dejected, 
   • astonished, 
   • confused (Ier. 14.9) ,
   • bewitched (Oih. 8.9) ; 
   • weary.

a rattlebox (Crotalaria pallida, formerly known as C. mucronata), known in many tropical countries, a small, weedy, shrubby legume with three-parted leaves, yellow flowers striped with red, and many-seeded pods to 5 cm long.

(probably pili, to cling, + -kana, nominalizer.) 
   • relation, relationship, 
   • kin, family.
gram. article, the part of speech: ke, ka, he, nā.
association, relationship, union, connection, meeting, joining, adhering, fitting.

• giant, 
   • large strapping fellow, 
   • country person, one living in the country; countrified.
gambling, betting, gambler; to bet, gamble. lit., to wager wealth.
a native variety of sugar cane, a yellow-green mutant of ʻakilolo; used in hana aloha, love sorcery, with the prayer for love to cling and hold fast.
name of a pair of stars, said to bring ʻōpelu fish.

a vine (Stictocardia tiliaefolia) in the morning-glory family, native from India eastward, possibly into Polynesia, long known in Hawaiʻi, as on roadsides and rocky shores. Flowers are funnel-shaped, rose-purple, about 5.1 cm in diameter, the leaves heartshaped.
shore, especially the area between high and low tides; near the shore.
name of one of the tapas in the game of pūhenehene.
hollow stone containing kukui oil used as a lamp (Malo 63); palm of the hand (stingy).
slow, as a vessel; unskilled, bungling, as in mechanical work.
sinking in, caving in, hollowing, as cheeks of an aged person; settling; bend, as in a U-shaped fish-hook.
gray, misty, smoky. fig., affectionate grief, pity.
tied tightly, not easily unfastened. fig., severe suffering.
recovered from sickness; well, after sickness; to get well, convalesce; filling out, as after loss of weight; sprouting, as a bud.
a parasitic isopod found clinging to the skin, gills, fins, mouths, and tails of fish.
the dark, invisible beyond, as on beyond the horizon or in the upper stratum. lit., back bosom.
a drink of either warm or cold water, with sugar and cream.
program, a term invented in the mid-1970s for the Hawaiian language radio program.
to have lost property by authority of a chief.
a soft, porous stone as used for polishing or for octopus lure sinkers
the pomegranate (Punica granatum), an ornamental and fruit-bearing shrub from Persia.
musty odor; rancid, moldy odor, as of mildewed clothes; stuffy or stale smell of a room long closed.
neat, tidy, in order, arranged, cared for, attended to, administered.
copyright; to copyright; to copy in any way, not necessarily properly.
design in tapa and patchwork quilts.
to assume the appearance of kala seaweed, said of octopus in the sea.
to come and go swiftly, as a puff or gust of wind.
extremity of life, extreme old age.
post set in the middle of each end of the house, supporting the ridgepole. fig., support, mainstay, as of a family.
a lua fighting stroke. lit., the smoke blows, the birds rage.
one of the native loosestrifes (Lysimachia hillebrandii). lit., thunder flower.
house post; post designating place of human sacrifice, said to be named for an ancient deity; center post. see illus. 1, illus. 2, illus. 3
the star Rigel, tutelary star of West Maui.
same as puhi₁,₂,₃; blowhole (preceded by ke).
yellow color; to appear yellow, as said of dawn or muddy water.

• soft, flabby, 
   • loose, to loosen, 
   • sagging, sag. 
   • sunken, sink,
   • deflated; deflate,  
   • fig., unenthusiastic, relaxed, weak.
to carry on the hip, as a child.
a tapa colored by beating in sandalwood.
a spiny climbing vine (Caesalpinia sepiaria) from India, first grown in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, by Father Celestino.  lit., Celestino flower.

• scattered, dispersed, routed, gone, 
   • tousled; every which way, as hair in the wind,
   • fine, crumbling.

a species of surgeonfish (Acanthurus xanthopterus and A. mata), up to 15 and 20 cm in length and brown or dull-gray in color. It resembles the palani in tough skin and strong smell but may be distinguished from the latter by a blue line across the soft part of the fin.
a gourd (Sicyos niihauensis), first collected and identified by H. St. John. cf. kūpala and (Neal 808).
false daisy (Eclipta alba).  lit., flower of the chief [or heaven]. Niʻihau.
loose, set free, released, taken off.

large woody vines (Bougainvillea spp.) from Brazil, bearing during their long flowering time masses of bright-colored bracts, which accompany small hidden flowers. Flower bracts are purple-red, rose-red, brick-red, and orange to whitish.
redup. of pulu₁, wet, moist, soaked, saturated...
seedlings, sprouts, cuttings, as of sugar cane.
one's child's parents-in-law or aunts and uncles by marriage; kāne, male, and wahine, female, may follow.
butterfly, moth, the Kamehameha butterfly (Vanessa tameamea).
to gum lehua flowers for the purpose of catching birds.
to rebuke mildly, as because of affection.
offspring of a chief and a mother of no rank. lit., little rain.
all together, in unison, united, cooperative. (cf. -walu, many, as in makawalu, olowalu.)
formerly, spouses sharing a spouse, as two husbands of a wife, or two wives of a husband; also, wives of brothers, husbands of sisters (no sexual privileges); sister-in-law (Ruta 1.15) .
fearful, afraid; to run off in fear.
lie, to tell a lie, cheat; liar.
to place high, or in a lofty or sacred place.
mealy, firm, not soft or soggy, as taro or sweet potato.
lazy, overstuffed with food. lit., lazy colon.
to fly or hurry as though on wings (ʻēheu).
to sew together, as sails; to lay together, as stones in a wall; to interlock.
heavy fog, mist. lit., water covering.
piece labor, pay by the job rather than according to time, as on sugar plantations; used in pidgin for any work that everyone should pitch in gladly to finish; contract labor. lit., finished pay.
to plait, weave, knit, braid; plaiting, weaving.
place in the grass house where host and guests visited, between the sleeping place and the door.
vexed, annoyed, discouraged, displeased (1-Nal. 20.43) , harassed, weary, offended, angry, upset.
to gather together; to go everywhere.
pillow, cushion, formerly made of pandanus; to use as a pillow (Kin. 28.18) . headrest (e.g. dentist's chair) (HE).
overcome by emotion, hysteria, passion, or an occult influence.
a strong wind blowing from a given direction in each locality, as a strong southeast wind in Kaʻū and Puna, Hawaiʻi, and at Kāneʻohe, Oʻahu. lit., blowing hard.

lignum vitae (Guaiacum officinale), a small tree from tropical America, with heavy, hard wood, useful for many purposes. The resin yields medicine and stain. The tree is also ornamental, each leaf with two or three pairs of rounded leaflets, the flowers blue and clustered, the fruits yellow and heart-shaped.
distant, aloof, unsociable, exclusive, as of a chief too high to mingle with others. lit., godly blood.
a wind famous in song noted on Kauaʻi, West Maui, and Niʻihau; according to (Emerson) (UL 196), the trade wind.
to talk glibly, brag. lit., watery mouth.

• to singe, as the feathers of a chicken before dressing it, or the hairs of a pig or dog by rolling it over hot oven stones; 
   • to pluck, as feathers from a fowl.
to talk glibly, brag. lit., watery mouth.

lignum vitae (Guaiacum officinale), a small tree from tropical America, with heavy, hard wood, useful for many purposes. The resin yields medicine and stain. The tree is also ornamental, each leaf with two or three pairs of rounded leaflets, the flowers blue and clustered, the fruits yellow and heart-shaped.
a wind famous in song noted on Kauaʻi, West Maui, and Niʻihau; according to (Emerson) (UL 196), the trade wind.
distant, aloof, unsociable, exclusive, as of a chief too high to mingle with others. lit., godly blood.

• to singe, as the feathers of a chicken before dressing it, or the hairs of a pig or dog by rolling it over hot oven stones; 
   • to pluck, as feathers from a fowl.
place names on Hawaiʻi, Kauaʻi, and Molokaʻi.
a heiau where hogs, bananas, and coconuts were sacrificed, but not human beings; a heiau for moʻo spirits.
careful, cautious about what one says.
stone from which octopus sinkers were made.
spirit, ghost; remains of the dead.
name recorded for a variety of sweet potato.
a file; formerly a rough stone used to grind and polish.
agricultural land term commonly used in the 1840s, especially on Maui; meaning unknown.

depository, closet, cabinet, vault, file, receptacle, savings, place for laying up things in safe-keeping; internal organs of the body, funds, treasury; fiscal. (wai₄ + iho, directional, + -na, nominalizer.) Numerous types of waihona are listed below.
all kinds of cultivated dahlias (Dahlia spp.), named for a town on Hawaiʻi where the plant was first grown.
to travel off the path or crookedly.

the paper mulberry (Broussonetia papyrifera), a small tree or shrub, from eastern Asia, known throughout the Pacific for its usefulness. It belongs to the fig or mulberry family. The bark was made into tough tapa used for clothing, bed clothes; it lasted longer than māmaki tapa.
to touch the tip, as of a spear.
redup. of welu₁, rag, ragged fragment; ragged, frayed, tattered...; shredded to bits.
a deep sea fish resembling the hāuliuli.

• opening, unfastening, taking off; 
   • solution, as of a problem.
a greeting of affection, similar to aloha; a salutation in a letter, in longer form as follows:
brick, named for Captain Winship, said to have brought the first bricks to Hawaiʻi.
